summary: A letter from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York to the Federal Bureau of Prisons regarding the provision of a modified laptop to inmate Ghislaine Maxwell for reviewing discovery materials in her criminal case. The laptop has been disabled for recording, gaming, and all communication capabilities.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The inmate at the Metropolitan Detention Center who is to receive a specially modified laptop for reviewing discovery in her criminal case.

persons.name: Audrey Strauss
persons.context: The Acting United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York who signed and submitted the letter.

persons.name: Silvio J. Mollo
persons.context: The building housing the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York is named after him.

connections.description: Strauss, as Acting U.S. Attorney, is overseeing the prosecution and logistical arrangements (like providing a laptop) for defendant Maxwell's case.

events.title: Laptop Provision Letter Sent
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office sends a letter to the Federal Bureau of Prisons detailing the provision of a modified laptop to Ghislaine Maxwell for case discovery review.

locations: Silvio J. Mollo Building (U.S. Attorney's Office, Southern District of New York)
Metropolitan Detention Center (where Ghislaine Maxwell is held)
keyFacts: A laptop was provided to Ghislaine Maxwell in November 2020 for the sole purpose of reviewing discovery in her criminal case (United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell).
The laptop was specially modified: its microphone and camera were disabled, it contained no game programs, and all communication capabilities (Wi-Fi, Bluetooth, Ethernet) were disabled.
The letter confirms Ghislaine Maxwell was an inmate at the Metropolitan Detention Center at the time.
The correspondence highlights the strict security and access controls placed on Maxwell's resources while in pre-trial detention.
